title: 109_s1172
content: The Act may be cited as the "Gynecologic Cancer Education and Awareness Act of 2005" or "Johanna's Law". Certain programs regarding gynecologic cancers are addressed in the Act. The "Gynecologic Cancer Education and Awareness Act of 2005" mandates a national public awareness campaign led by the Secretary of Health and Human Services to educate women about gynecologic cancers through written materials and public service announcements. The Act mandates a national public awareness campaign to educate women about gynecologic cancers through public service announcements and written materials. Grants will be provided for testing outreach strategies to increase awareness among women and healthcare providers. The Secretary shall give preference in making grants for gynecologic cancer education and treatment to applicants with expertise in working with high-risk women and establishing linkages between healthcare professionals, hospitals, payers, and state health departments. Grants can only be made if an application is submitted. The Secretary will make grants for gynecologic cancer education and treatment to applicants with expertise in working with high-risk women and establishing healthcare linkages. Grants require a specific application with necessary agreements and assurances. At least five grants will be awarded, and information provided must align with current medical knowledge. A report to Congress is due by February 1, 2009. The Secretary will submit a report to Congress summarizing demonstration project activities, evaluating their effectiveness in increasing early detection of gynecologic cancers, and identifying barriers to early detection and treatment. $15,000,000 is authorized for a national public awareness campaign for fiscal years 2006 through 2008. Demonstration projects for outreach and education strategies are authorized to receive $30,000,000 for fiscal years 2006 through 2008. Up to 9 percent of the funds can be used for administration, technical assistance, and evaluation purposes.
